001// Copyright (c) Choreo contributors
002
003package choreo.auto;
004
005import static edu.wpi.first.wpilibj.Alert.AlertType.kError;
006
007import choreo.Choreo;
008import edu.wpi.first.networktables.NetworkTable;
009import edu.wpi.first.networktables.NetworkTableInstance;
010import edu.wpi.first.networktables.StringArrayEntry;
011import edu.wpi.first.networktables.StringEntry;
012import edu.wpi.first.wpilibj.Alert;
013import edu.wpi.first.wpilibj.DriverStation;
014import edu.wpi.first.wpilibj.IterativeRobotBase;
015import java.util.HashMap;
016import java.util.Map;
017import java.util.function.Function;
018
019/**
020 * An Choreo specific {@code SendableChooser} that allows for the selection of {@link AutoRoutine}s
021 * at runtime via a <a
022 * href="https://docs.wpilib.org/en/stable/docs/software/dashboards/index.html#dashboards">Dashboard</a>.
023 *
024 * <p>This chooser takes a <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lazy_loading">lazy loading</a>
025 * approach to {@link AutoRoutine}s, only generating the {@link AutoRoutine} when it is selected.
026 * This approach has the benefit of not loading all autos on startup, but also not loading the auto
027 * during auto start causing a delay.
028 *
029 * <p>Once the {@link AutoChooser} is made you can add {@link AutoRoutine}s to it using the {@link
030 * #addAutoRoutine(String, AutoRoutineGenerator)} method. Unlike {@code SendableChooser} this
031 * chooser has to be updated every cycle by calling the {@link #update()} method in your {@link
032 * IterativeRobotBase#robotPeriodic()}.
033 *
034 * <p>You can retrieve the {@link AutoRoutine} that is currently selected by calling the {@link
035 * #getSelectedAutoRoutine()} method.
036 */
037public class AutoChooser {
038  /** A function that generates an {@link AutoRoutine} from an {@link AutoFactory}. */
039  public static interface AutoRoutineGenerator extends Function<AutoFactory, AutoRoutine> {
040    /** A generator that returns an auto routine that does nothing */
041    static final AutoRoutineGenerator NONE = factory -> AutoFactory.VOID_ROUTINE;
042  }
043
044  private static final String NONE_NAME = "Nothing";
045
046  private static final Alert notAnOption =
047      Choreo.alert("Selected an auto that isn't an option", kError);
048
049  private final HashMap<String, AutoRoutineGenerator> autoRoutines =
050      new HashMap<>(Map.of(NONE_NAME, AutoRoutineGenerator.NONE));
051
052  private final StringEntry selected, active;
053  private final StringArrayEntry options;
054
055  private final AutoFactory factory;
056
057  private String lastAutoRoutineName = NONE_NAME;
058  private AutoRoutine lastAutoRoutine = AutoRoutineGenerator.NONE.apply(null);
059
060  /**
061   * Constructs a new {@link AutoChooser}.
062   *
063   * @param factory The auto factory to use for AutoRoutine creation.
064   * @param tableName The name of the network table to use for the chooser. Passing in an empty
065   *     string or null will put this chooser at the root of the network tables.
066   */
067  public AutoChooser(AutoFactory factory, String tableName) {
068    this.factory = factory;
069
070    if (tableName == null) {
071      tableName = "";
072    }
073    String path =
074        (tableName.isEmpty()) ? NetworkTable.normalizeKey(tableName, true) : "" + "/AutoChooser";
075    NetworkTable table = NetworkTableInstance.getDefault().getTable(path);
076
077    selected = table.getStringTopic("selected").getEntry(NONE_NAME);
078    table.getStringTopic(".type").publish().set("String Chooser");
079    table.getStringTopic("default").publish().set(NONE_NAME);
080    active = table.getStringTopic("active").getEntry(NONE_NAME);
081    options =
082        table.getStringArrayTopic("options").getEntry(autoRoutines.keySet().toArray(new String[0]));
083  }
084
085  /**
086   * Update the auto chooser.
087   *
088   * <p>This method should be called every cycle in the {@link IterativeRobotBase#robotPeriodic()}.
089   * It will check if the selected auto routine has changed and update the active AutoRoutine.
090   *
091   * <p>The AutoRoutine can only be updated when the robot is disabled and connected to
092   * DriverStation. If the chooser in your dashboard says {@code BAD} the {@link AutoChooser} has
093   * not responded to the selection yet and you need to disable the robot to update it.
094   */
095  public void update() {
096    if (DriverStation.isDisabled()
097        && DriverStation.isDSAttached()
098        && DriverStation.getAlliance().isPresent()) {
099      String selectStr = selected.get();
100      if (selectStr.equals(lastAutoRoutineName)) return;
101      if (!autoRoutines.containsKey(selectStr)) {
102        selected.set(NONE_NAME);
103        selectStr = NONE_NAME;
104        notAnOption.set(true);
105      } else {
106        notAnOption.set(false);
107      }
108      lastAutoRoutineName = selectStr;
109      lastAutoRoutine = autoRoutines.get(lastAutoRoutineName).apply(this.factory);
110      active.set(lastAutoRoutineName);
111    }
112  }
113
114  /**
115   * Add an AutoRoutine to the chooser.
116   *
117   * <p>The options of the chooser are actually of type {@link AutoRoutineGenerator}. This is a
118   * function that takes an {@link AutoFactory} and returns a {@link AutoRoutine}. These functions
119   * can be static, a lambda or belong to a local variable.
120   *
121   * <p>This is done to load AutoRoutines when and only when they are selected, in order to save
122   * memory and file loading time for unused AutoRoutines.
123   *
124   * <p>One way to keep this clean is to make an `Autos` class that all of your subsystems/resources
125   * are <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dependency_injection">dependency injected</a> into.
126   * Then create methods inside that class that take an {@link AutoFactory} and return an {@link
127   * AutoRoutine}.
128   *
129   * <h3>Example:</h3>
130   *
131   * <pre><code>
132   * AutoChooser chooser;
133   * Autos autos = new Autos(swerve, shooter, intake, feeder);
134   * Robot() {
135   *   chooser = new AutoChooser(Choreo.createAutoFactory(...), "/Choosers");
136   *   chooser.addAutoRoutine("4 Piece right", autos::fourPieceRight);
137   *   chooser.addAutoRoutine("4 Piece Left", autos::fourPieceLeft);
138   *   chooser.addAutoRoutine("3 Piece Close", autos::threePieceClose);
139   *   chooser.addAutoRoutine("Just Shoot", factory -> factory.commandAsAutoRoutine(shooter.shoot()));
140   * }
141   * </code></pre>
142   *
143   * @param name The name of the auto routine.
144   * @param generator The function that generates the auto routine.
145   */
146  public void addAutoRoutine(String name, AutoRoutineGenerator generator) {
147    autoRoutines.put(name, generator);
148    options.set(autoRoutines.keySet().toArray(new String[0]));
149  }
150
151  /**
152   * Get the currently selected {@link AutoRoutine}.
153   *
154   * <h3>Recommended Usage</h3>
155   *
156   * Scheduling it as a command.
157   *
158   * <pre><code>
159   * AutoChooser chooser = ...;
160   *
161   * public void autonomousInit() {
162   *   CommandScheduler.getInstance().schedule(chooser.getSelectedAutoRoutine().cmd());
163   * }
164   * </code></pre>
165   *
166   * Polling it yourself.
167   *
168   * <pre><code>
169   * AutoChooser chooser = ...;
170   * AutoRoutine routine = chooser.getSelectedAutoRoutine();
171   *
172   * public void autonomousInit() {
173   *   routine = chooser.getSelectedAutoRoutine();
174   * }
175   *
176   * public void autonomousPeriodic() {
177   *  routine.poll();
178   * }
179   *
180   * public void autonomousExit() {
181   *   routine.reset();
182   * }
183   * </code></pre>
184   *
185   * @return The currently selected {@link AutoRoutine}.
186   */
187  public AutoRoutine getSelectedAutoRoutine() {
188    return lastAutoRoutine;
189  }
190
191  /**
192   * Get the {@link AutoFactory} used by this chooser.
193   *
194   * @return The {@link AutoFactory} used by this chooser.
195   */
196  public AutoFactory factory() {
197    return factory;
198  }
199}
